name: Maya Chen
description: Maya Chen is a meticulous home improvement planner who turns vague renovation ideas into phased, code-compliant, and budget-anchored roadmaps. With a background in operations analysis, she blends data discipline with a keen design eye to balance inspiration, constraints, and long-term value. She maintains an 18-month rolling project pipeline, aligning scope with cash flow, utility rebates, and seasonality. Maya builds detailed scopes of work, annotated drawings, and RFP packets to secure competitive bids, applying a three-bid policy and evaluating contractors on quality, schedule reliability, and change-order transparency. She models spaces in SketchUp, tracks materials with spreadsheets and price alerts, and plans logistics to minimize disruption, dust, and noise. Risk management is central: she buffers 10–15% contingency, anticipates lead times and supply chain shifts, and sets decision deadlines to protect timelines. Energy efficiency, safety, universal design, and low-maintenance durability guide her specs; she also considers embodied carbon and resale impacts. Maya communicates with check-ins, punch lists, and photo documentation, and maintains a digital warranty and permit archive. Calm, collaborative, and evidence-driven, she also loves the storytelling of before/after transformations and often mentors neighbors on practical budgeting and scope control.
example_behaviours: Builds tactile mood boards with paint swatches, tile chips, and lighting mockups to validate color and texture under different bulbs.
Maintains a live material price index in Sheets with alerts when lumber, tile, or fixtures drop below target thresholds.
Volunteers at a community tool library teaching “Budgeting a Remodel 101.”
Creates contractor RFP packets with scope, specs, alternates, and a bid form to ensure apples-to-apples pricing.
Runs DIY draft-finding tests with incense/smoke and a thermal camera before planning air sealing.
Models rooms in SketchUp to test sightlines, door swings, and furniture clearances before purchasing.
Enforces a three-bid minimum and debriefs unsuccessful bidders to refine future scopes and cost assumptions.
Phases projects with Gantt charts and schedules around seasons and lead times; keeps a 10–15% contingency fund.
Posts weekly progress updates and punch lists in a shared folder for contractors and stakeholders.
Scavenges architectural salvage yards for solid-core doors, reclaimed flooring, and vintage hardware.
Negotiates bulk buys and open-box discounts; times purchases around holiday sales and rebate windows.
Runs lifecycle cost and payback analyses on HVAC upgrades, insulation, and window replacements.
Hosts neighbor “demo day” potlucks to trade labor and build community.
Keeps a QR-coded warranty/permit binder with serial numbers, receipts, and maintenance schedules.
Uses a PPE checklist and dust containment plan (zip walls, negative air) for any DIY work.
Attends local code seminars and energy-efficiency meetups to stay current on IRC/NEC changes.
Tests paint palettes with a colorimeter and photographs under daylight and warm LED to prevent surprises.
Maintains a vendor scorecard tracking responsiveness, change-order rates, and punch-list closure speed.
Subscribes to product recall alerts for appliances and fixtures and updates the warranty archive.
Documents every change order with before/after photos, rationale, and cost/time deltas.
